M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable family law principles governing custody and visitation.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20)

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: These actions directly undermine the child’s educational stability and welfare and are inconsistent with the terms and spirit of the existing custody order and M.G.L. c. 208, § 31, which prioritizes the child’s best interests.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 & 31.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31, and under Massachusetts case law, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a material change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court’s continuing equitable authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and M.G.L. c. 208, § 37 empowers it to revise custody and visitation provisions as justice and the welfare of the child may require.

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 37.proposition: The Court’s continuing equitable authority under M.G.L. c. 215, § 6 and M.G.L. c. 208, § 37 empowers it to revise custody and visitation provisions as justice and the welfare of the child may require.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court in Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), held that the paramount consideration in all custody determinations is the best interest of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: This opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly references the child’s welfare, but in the excerpt provided it does not clearly restate or emphasize the overarching doctrinal rule that the ‘paramount consideration’ in custody determinations is the best interest of the child. The focus here is on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects, not on articulating the general best‑interest standard. Without an express statement in this text, Custody of Vaughn cannot be reliably cited as authority for that specific formulation, even though it is consistent with that principle.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court in Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), and Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), held that the paramount consideration in all custody determinations is the best interest of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30, “removal must be in the best interests of the child” and repeatedly describes the best interests of the child as the controlling/paramount consideration in resolving the custody/removal issues. While Yannas focuses on a removal dispute, it frames the analysis within the overarching rule that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody-related determinations. Thus it directly supports the proposition that the paramount consideration in all custody determinations is the best interest of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Where circumstances have deteriorated or a parent’s conduct impairs a child’s welfare, modification is warranted.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on the standard for authorizing removal when parents share joint physical custody. The court discusses ‘cause shown’ as equivalent to the child’s best interests and references the ALI principle that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not hold that deteriorated circumstances or a parent’s conduct impairing welfare, by themselves, warrant modification. The opinion is about whether to permit removal, not about modifying custody due to deteriorated conditions or parental misconduct in the abstract, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part: ‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities…’ … ‘(4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests… taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’ … [T]he judge… determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Where circumstances have deteriorated or a parent’s conduct impairs a child’s welfare, modification is warranted.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion does involve a modification judgment, but the discussion is about (1) how to account for Social Security disability dependency benefits in calculating child support, (2) attachment of assets, and (3) the legal standard and findings required to change legal custody. It does not articulate or apply a rule that modification is warranted when circumstances deteriorate or a parent’s conduct impairs a child’s welfare; rather, it recites the statutory ‘material and substantial change’ and ‘best interests’ standards without tying them specifically to deteriorated circumstances or harmful parental conduct. Thus it is not proper authority for the quoted proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court has recognized that consistent interference with a child’s schooling or routine may justify modification to protect the child’s educational welfare.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss interference with a child’s schooling or routine, nor does it address modification to protect educational welfare. Instead, it reiterates the general principle that custody decisions must be based on the child’s overall welfare and that custody should not be used to punish a parent, and remands for further findings on comparative parental environments. It therefore does not establish or recognize the specific proposition about consistent interference with schooling justifying modification.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Similarly, failure to support a child’s academic needs may demonstrate an inability to act jointly in the child’s best interests, justifying adjustment of legal or physical custody.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with modification of physical custody between parents of twins and focuses on sibling separation, children’s stated preferences, parental fitness, and best-interests analysis. It does not address a parent’s failure to support a child’s academic needs, nor does it use educational support (or lack thereof) as a basis for adjusting either legal or physical custody. Accordingly, it does not establish or affirm the specific principle that failure to support academic needs demonstrates inability to act jointly in the child’s best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children. … We have examined both the record from the proceedings below and the judge’s notes from his private interview with Rebecca and find no evidence from which the judge properly could have concluded that a split physical custody arrangement would be in the childrens’ best interests.”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. 190 (1981).proposition: Denial of educational attendance or routine has been viewed as "contrary to the child’s welfare" within meaning of Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. 190 (1981), and Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. 190 (1981).support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Hale v. Hale is an early 19th‑century Massachusetts contract/unjust enrichment case concerning recovery of money advanced, not a family-law or child-welfare matter. It nowhere discusses educational attendance, children’s routines, or the standard of conduct ‘contrary to the child’s welfare.’ The proposition about denial of educational attendance being contrary to a child’s welfare is therefore not supported by this decision and misattributes its subject matter.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. 190 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “The true ground of the action is, that, by reason of the contract, Larkin was led to confide in the engagement of the defendant, so far as to advance his own money for him; and the defendant, and the other subscribers, having made Larkin the trustee, to receive and appropriate the money, for objects of importance to them, were bound in equity and good conscience to restore it. The only question which could arise in this case was, whether Larkin was induced to advance his money by the subscription…”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Denial of educational attendance or routine has been viewed as "contrary to the child’s welfare" within meaning of Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. 190 (1981), and Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: Rolde is a custody/visitation and property-division case that repeatedly applies the general ‘best interests/welfare of the child’ standard, but it does not discuss denial of educational attendance or disruption of school routines as a circumstance that is ‘contrary to the child’s welfare.’ Its references to disagreements over “schooling” and “education” are in the context of parental conflict and the impracticability of joint custody, not as a standalone principle that denying educational attendance per se violates the child’s welfare. Therefore it does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: The trial judge stated that joint custody would be inappropriate where “the parties are not only personally very antagonistic towards each other but also disagree with respect to child rearing both in the major areas such as schooling, medical treatment, religion, education, but more important in the day to day philosophy of discipline and child rearing.” … [T]he judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare.

Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.raw_text: Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.proposition: The Plaintiff’s request does not seek to deprive the Defendant of a meaningful relationship with the child but rather to ensure continuity of education and stability, both essential to the child’s best interests as noted in Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984) and Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.support_reasoning: This case focuses on parental unfitness, sibling placements, and the need for detailed findings and orders regarding custody and visitation. While it discusses best interests in terms of stability of placement, maintaining sibling bonds, and keeping children within the natural family, it does not articulate a principle that a court should favor continuity of education or stability in the sense invoked by the proposition, nor does it frame best interests as ensuring continuity of schooling rather than affecting parental relationships. The proposition’s specific emphasis on continuity of education and non‑deprivation of a meaningful parent–child relationship is not derived from this opinion.
Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’… The judge’s findings in this case are deficient in that he failed to address two issues: the importance of the sibling relationship, and whether placement of all three children with the paternal grandparents would be in the best interests of the children.… It has also been our policy to keep children within the natural family whenever possible.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The Plaintiff’s request does not seek to deprive the Defendant of a meaningful relationship with the child but rather to ensure continuity of education and stability, both essential to the child’s best interests as noted in Care and Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704 (1984) and Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The proposition claims Hugo stands for continuity of education and stability as essential to a child’s best interests and that a request does not deprive the other parent of a meaningful relationship. Hugo is not a relocation or parenting-time case between two parents, and it does not discuss preserving a ‘meaningful relationship’ with a parent in the context of a move. Rather, it is an adoption/best interests placement dispute between two non-parent caretakers, focusing on developmental needs, stability vs. transition, and the comparative ability of caretakers, not on ensuring continuity of education in the sense used in relocation cases or preserving a noncustodial parent’s relationship. While the opinion recognizes stability as an important factor, it does not articulate the specific proposition asserted.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”
